stem: For each assessment finding, click to specify if the finding is consistent with right-sided heart failure, left-sided heart failure, or neither.

itemContext.sbar: John Smith is a 72-year-old male admitted with shortness of breath and lower extremity edema. He has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: BNP: 800 pg/mL, Chest X-ray: Cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion

rationale.correct: Right-sided heart failure leads to systemic fluid retention, causing edema and JVD. Left-sided heart failure leads to pulmonary congestion, causing crackles and shortness of breath.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect selections indicate a lack of understanding of the pathophysiology of right- and left-sided heart failure.
clinicalPearls: BNP is a marker for heart failure.
Crackles indicate fluid in the lungs.
rationale.questionTrap: Students may confuse the symptoms of right- and left-sided heart failure.
rationale.mnemonic: L for Lungs (Left-sided heart failure causes lung symptoms), R for Rest of the body (Right-sided heart failure causes systemic symptoms).
